page.lettertext:
fol.210r
Belgia 1591 31 Au
g
To my L. Trea
s
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
May it please yo
r
good L. I send yo
u
heer
e copye of
Cortekens
confession, but w
th
out
e Interrogatories, as they say they were sent
fr
o
e
states of Zeland
, albeit I am
swaded they will not willingly
let mee see them. And as I am informed, they have examined
him again upon new Interrogatories; to what effect I know not,
nor yet what answere he hath made. For they deale in these
matters very Jalously w
th
mee, & more I see I shall no knowe
th
e
I must of necessity, & is likely oth
r
wise to be signified to mee
Of that w
ch
conc
r
ned
e matter of peace, there ys nothing yet
im
ted to
e body of this
Councel
but ev
r
y man a
te ys made
acquainted w
th
it: w
ch
they do, as I suppose, leaste
e brute of
such a motion, wh
e
e vulg
r
people do not rightly und
r
stand yt,
should occasyon furder trouble, then they shall after be able, to
appease when they would.
Sir Edward Norreis
hath written
hether to
e Councell, requesting for Corteken to have him
released, alleaging
t
he had employed him about her
Ma
t
affaires, & in case they would retaine him as a lawfull prisoner
he should be forced for his ransome to write unto her Hig
nes
, But
they answered nothing to his l
re
. What hath passed in conference
betwene me &
vand
r
wercke
I have c
r
tified in my last, w
ch
is all
the occasyon I have had to speake of
t
matter, to any of them all
nor till I heare from yo
r
L. I know not furder what to saie to
coull
r
that Treaty between
e
Governo
r
& Corteken astouching a
peace. There are certaine point
confessed, w
ch
verify those
abuses, wherw
th
e Gouverno
r
ys charged in
e matters of
contribution, w
ch
I see them heer inclined to send unto her Ma
tye
,
w
th
all theyr oth
r
informations, therby to justify whatsoever they
have writen heertofore, but what course in conclusyon wilbe
tak
e
by them I cannot yet conjecture. for in theyr publick
assembly yt was never yet proposed to be finally resolved, & I
finde them diversly affected in theyr private c
o
ications: some of
th
e
urging to send for him hether, & to
ceed against his
dealing
by order of Justice, others requiring that some should be
deputed to go to
Ostend,
& there examine & determin, as shall
be thought expedient. There are also some that think it
best that all theyr informations should be sent unto her Ma
ty
w
th
earnest request to revoke him fr
o
thense. Wherto there are
divers that would willingly condescend, but they would have
e
garrison heerafter to be kept by a Governo
r
& souldiers of the
Countrey. But to all these opinions there are among th
e
selves
that do make oppositions, for first they malign that he
will not come, altho he were sent for; & to send unto him thether
fol.210v
To my L. T
re
r Au
g
31 1591
Belgia: 1591: Au
g
they thinke it not convenient, where matters are so evident, nor for
the Councels reputation. To pray her Hig
nes
to revoke him, they
hold it prejudiciall to
e lib
r
ties of
e countreys, consydering it is a
matt
r
in theyr disposition. That w
ch
is least gainsayd, is the
changing of
e garrison, w
ch
yet they are in dout will not
greatly please her Ma
ty
, to whose good liking, to say truly,
they are willinger then they have bin to conforme th
e
selves,
These thing
are but privately thus debated, & nothing yet set
downe by waie of resolution. Howbeit I attend every houre
theyr meeting upon it, w
ch
I thinke wilbe g
na
l aswell of
e
states
as of
e Councel.
